ca.cgjennings.ui

Class GestureToolkit

  • java.lang.Object
    • ca.cgjennings.ui.GestureToolkit

  • public final class GestureToolkit
extends Object
    The gesture toolkit allows Swing components to listen for gesture-based input such as multitouch swipes and pinches. The toolkit provides support for the following kinds of gestures: zoom in, zoom out, rotation, and swipes in the four basic directions (up, down, left, right). It also provides support for custom, device-specific gestures (see below).

    Since gesture detection is platform-dependent and is not a standard feature of Swing, the toolkit relies on platform-specific service providers. The following process is used to try to locate a suitable service provider:

    1. If the system property ca.cgjennings.ui.GestureProvider is defined as "false", then the dummy provider described below will be used and no further attempt will be made to locate a provider. (This effectively disables the toolkit.)
    2. If instead the system property ca.cgjennings.ui.GestureProvider is defined to be the fully qualified name of a class that implements the GestureToolkit.Provider interface, then the toolkit attempts to load and instantiate the named class.
    3. If none of the above steps succeeds, then a no-op provider will be used. In this case, it is still possible to add and remove gesture listeners, but no events will occur. When this provider is used, isAvailable() returns false.

    Service providers can define additional, custom gesture types that can be detected through the abstract gesture events provided by the toolkit. Each custom event type is identified by a unique string that is available to listeners. Providers can also pass an arbitrary object to listeners in order to contain any additional parameters required by the event.

    Since:
    3.0

    • Method Detail

      • addListenerTo

        public static void addListenerTo(JRootPane root,
                                 GestureListener listener)
        Adds a gesture listener to the specified root container. If a provider is available, and if the underlying hardware is compatible with the provider, then GestureEvents will be received for the event types supported by the provider.

        Note that failing to remove a listener may result in a resource leak.

        Parameters:
        root - the container to add a listener to
        listener - the listener to call in response to gesture events
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if either parameter is null
        See Also:
        removeListenerFrom(javax.swing.JRootPane, ca.cgjennings.ui.GestureListener), GestureEvent

      • getCustomGestureIDs

        public static List<String> getCustomGestureIDs()
        Returns a list of the unique identifier strings of any custom gestures supported by the provider. If the provider does not support any custom gestures, an empty list will be returned. The caller should assume that the returned list is immutable.
        Returns:
        a (possibly empty) list of custom gesture IDs

      • getStatusString

        public static String getStatusString()
        Returns a block of text describing all available providers and their status.
        Returns:
        a debugging status string

      • isAvailable

        public static boolean isAvailable()
        Returns true if a gesture provider is available. If this returns false, the other methods in the toolkit can still be called but they will have no practical effect. If it returns true, then there is a gesture provider available and it is capable of recognizing at least one type of gesture event. Note that there is no guarantee that the underlying hardware is available to actually generate the events supported by a provider.
        Returns:
        true if a gesture provider is available

      • removeListenerFrom

        public static void removeListenerFrom(JRootPane root,
                                      GestureListener listener)
        Adds a gesture listener to the specified component. If a provider is available, and if the underlying hardware is compatible with the provider, then GestureEvents will be received for the event types supported by the provider.
        Parameters:
        root - the container to add a listener to
        listener - the listener to call in response to gesture events
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if either parameter is null
        See Also:
        addListenerTo(javax.swing.JRootPane, ca.cgjennings.ui.GestureListener), GestureEvent
